results.title: Gaps
results.material_description:
Single channel, High Definition Digital Video.
'Gaps' is a single-channel video with one channel of sound [one stereo pair], which features contemporary dance and occasional dialogue spoken by the performers both as diagetic and voiceover sound. The key to a successful installation is presenting the work in such a way that the content takes precedence over any installation elements. The image should be as large and as clearly visible (i.e. not obscured by columns, other works etc) as is reasonable and comfortable for viewers in proportion to the space, and the audio levels should enable the dialogue to be clearly and easily heard. While projection in a dedicated, sound-locked space is ideal, the work can also be shown on a monitor with headphones. David Rosetzky did mention that this work would not be appropriate for online exhibitions, as it prohibits the viewer from experiencing the work with high quality image and sound.
There is no equipment dedicated or part of this particular work. Equipment should be selected for its ability to display the work at suitable image and sound quality.

Equipment used for ACMI installation (in ACMI's Gallery 2) is listed in the document:
"B2003044_Gaps_CommissionsPreservationQA.docx" linked to this record in the "Documentation" window.
results.brief_description:
One of Australia’s finest video artists, Rosetzky’s captivating works have been exhibited widely throughout Australia and internationally. ‘Gaps’ embodies Rosetzky’s ongoing exploration of personal identity and the relationship - or ‘gaps’ - between self and other through speech, movement and dance.
Rosetzky’s collaborators on ‘Gaps’ include choreographer and performer Stephanie Lake, (who also choreographed ‘How to Feel’ 2011) co-writer Anna Zagala, and performers, Jessie Oshodi, Lee Serle, Rani Pramesti and Dimitri Baveas.
Drawing from material Rosetzky gathered conducting interviews with his cast, this new work is an oblique survey of the transition from rehearsal to performance, in both art and life.
The artist’s process involved in-depth workshopping of the material with the performers, who come from acting and dance disciplines. Lake’s choreography, which integrates naturalistic and stylised movements, was also developed with input from the cast and Rosetzky during this rehearsal period. Long time collaborator David Franzke provides the sound design.

production_dates.notes:
Co-commissioned by ACMI and Carriageworks (Sydney).
David Rosetzky: Gaps will be a free exhibition at ACMI from 5 August 2014 to 8 February 2015.
The co-commission of Gaps by ACMI and Carriageworks has been assisted by the Australian Government through the Australian Council for the Arts, its arts funding and advisory body.

results.title: 9.5mm Pathé-Baby camera and projector
results.brief_description: The Pathé-Baby camera and projector was an inexpensive and easy-to-use amateur film system introduced in 1922. It used 9.5mm film with central perforations.

constellations_primary.name: 9.5mm Pathe-Baby and parents behaving badly
constellations_primary.description: A look at the link between the Pathé-Baby system and animation, as well as the relationship between cinematic parents and their children.

results.description:
The Pathé-Baby camera and projector was an inexpensive and easy-to-use amateur film system introduced in 1922. It used 9.5mm film with central perforations. This unique film width made it easy to duplicate commercial films for home use, and the hand-cranked projector took up to 60 feet of film.

The portability and simplicity of the Pathé-Baby made the system widely popular internationally. This one was used by pioneering Australian aviator John Robertson Duigan MC to document early aviation and his home life. Having built the first Australian-made aircraft, Duigan definitely had something worth capturing.
description_for_label:
The Pathé-Baby camera and projector was an inexpensive and easy-to-use amateur film system introduced in 1922. It used 9.5mm film with central perforations. This unique film width made it easy to duplicate commercial films for home use, and the hand-cranked projector took up to 60 feet of film.

The portability and simplicity of the Pathé-Baby made the system widely popular internationally. This one was used by pioneering Australian aviator John Robertson Duigan MC to document early aviation and his home life. Having built the first Australian-made aircraft, Duigan definitely had something worth capturing.

results.title: Abakanowicz in Australia
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Crafts Council of Australia, Malcolm Otton and Christopher McGill
results.brief_description: Polish artist Magdalena Abakanowicz prepares for an exhibition of her work in Australia. We see her exhibits of large rope, hessian and string three-dimensional forms. She comments upon her intended purpose in working with such materials. Narrated by Margaret Throsby.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Film Australia, Crafts Council of Australia, Malcolm Otton and Christopher McGill

results.title: Be smart... don't start
results.brief_description: Especially designed for elementary grades at school, this film looks at cigarette smoking and the hazards of starting the habit. It presents opposing opinions and claims of cigarette manufacturers and medical men in an effort to create a lifetime mental attitude toward smoking at this critical age level.

results.title: Touch the Sun : Captain Johnno (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation, Jane Ballantyne and Mario Andreacchio
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Touch the Sun Series”.
Johnno, an energetic and sensitive 10 year old, resides in a small coastal fishing town. His father’s inability to come to terms with Johnno’s deafness exacerbates their already troubled relationship. To curb Johnno’s rebelliousness his father proposes to send him to a “special school”. On learning of this plan Johnno flees to a nearby island to live like Robinson Crusoe. An Italian fisherman, who has earlier befriended Johnno, finds him on the island and endeavours to persuade him to return and face his problems. Rated: G

results.title: Touch the Sun : Princess Kate (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation and George Ogilvie
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘Touch the Sun’.
Thirteen year old Kate’s world is turned topsy turvy when she learns she is adopted. Unaware of the pain she is causing her adoptive family, Kate searches for her “real” parents. Her unexpected arrival on the doorstep of her natural mother stirs up mixed emotions. Kate succeeds in befriending her half-sister May before returning home to her adoptive parents with a new understanding of herself and her relationships. Rated: G.

results.title: Touch the Sun: Peter and Pompey
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation, Margot McDonald and Michael Carson
results.brief_description: Peter, Margaret and Wayne discover a Roman boat in a cave that contains the manuscript of young Pompey. The discovery changes the tiny little town of Gamma into a brash, hyped-up tourist centre. The children also find that their lives change too - and they don’t like what is happening. The manuscript found in the boat reveals that the boat is cursed and, until the boat is destroyed it will continue to curse anyone who comes into contact with it. The children decide that in order to save Gamma they must finally carry out the drastic act of destroying the boat.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Children’s Television Foundation, Margot McDonald and Michael Carson

results.title: Touch the Sun : Top enders (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation, Jill Robb and Jackie McKimmie
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘Touch the Sun’.
Alice, a runaway from home, meets on the road Nick, an Aboriginal boy in pursuit of his uncle. Stealing a car they traverse a treacherous stretch of desert road. When the car runs out of petrol they set out on foot, only to become lost. With the harsh desert conditions threatening their survival, Alice and Mick reflect on their actions and their families from which they have fled.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Children’s Television Foundation, Jill Robb and Jackie McKimmie
